intro: Selago squarrosa, commonly known as the hairy sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Australia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes caraway and parsley, and is characterized by its finely hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. It thrives in sandy soils and is often found in coastal and inland dunes. Selago squarrosa is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in harsh environments.
